snippet: As one of the world’s most wired societies, South Korea has embraced the Web, but a recent crackdown on Internet freedom has drawn accusations of censorship.
abstract: South Korea's avid policing of social media is a significant disconnect for a thriving democracy that once saw the Web as one way to catch up with the world’s top economies; critics of President Lee Myung-bak’s government agree that its conservative streak is a driver behind the Internet crackdown, but also argue that prohibitions on profanity and other online activities have become a convenient excuse to silence critics.
lead_paragraph: As one of the world’s most wired societies, South Korea has embraced the Web, but a recent crackdown on Internet freedom has drawn accusations of censorship.

headline.seo: Critics See South Korea Internet Curbs as Censorship
headline.main: Korea Policing the Net. Twist? It’s South Korea.
headline.print_headline: Korea Policing Internet. Twist? It’s South Korea.
